newsitem.title: USA: US budget talks on domestic spending end for day.
newsitem.headline: US budget talks on domestic spending end for day.

text.p: Congressional leaders and White House officials said they discussed domestic spending issues at a meeting Wednesday, and said it was going to be a difficult area in which to reach agreement.
But they said they were going to continue to work on it.

"We had a very thorough discussion but as far as coming up with any conclusions I believe that that will have to wait for another day on appropriations," Senate Budget Committee Chairman Pete Domenici said.

"In these kind of processes if we look a little bit down it's just because the processes are very difficult and in my opinion it's sort of the darkness before the dawn comes," the New Mexico Republican said.
"We cannot say a lot was accomplished today, but it's fair to say we have a general understanding and we're prepared to roll up our sleeves and do some more work on this overall area," he added.
White House Budget Director Franklin Raines described Wednesday's talks as "very good frank discussion about one of the toughest areas that we are going to have to tackle."
House Budget Committee Chairman John Kasich, an Ohio Republican, said any final agreement on domestic spending would unlikely please any side.

"If we reach an agreement at the end of the day, no one is going to be happy with what we do in discretionary spending, that's fair to say," he said. "The administration's not going to be happy, we're not going to be happy."
Republicans are seeking deeper domestic spending cuts from the White House, said Sen. Frank Lautenberg of New Jersey and the ranking Democrat on the budget committee.
Thursday's budget meeting will focus on tax cut proposals.
